text.p: These are the highlights in the Bosnian press on Wednesday. Reuter has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- Croat member of collective presidency, Kresimir Zubak, said he agrees with British Foreign Minister Robin Cook that all revenues and expenditures in Bosnia must be transparent and reported publicly.
- Zubak says he informed the British foreign minister about accelerated return of Croat refugees to central Bosnia.
- Deputies of Bosnia's House of Peoples adopted laws on protection of domestic production against imports and law on product quality control.

- State television editor-in-chief, Esad Cerovic, says the company's main board had adopted a draft law which would create a network covering both Serb and Moslem-Croat entities with two channels, one public and one commerical.
- Drago Bilandzija, federation minister of finance, says custom benefits will probably be revoked in September by the federation parliament.
- Federation banking agency says 40 percent of the banks in the Moslem-Croat federation lack minimum capital reserves of 2.5 million German marks ($1.4 million).
- Banking agency president Izudin Kesetovic says some 50 banks which are violating legal regulations will be closed down.
- The commander of the NATO-led Stabilisation Force, General William Crouch, is due to hand over his duties to General Eric Shinseki in a ceremony in Sarajevo on Wednesday.
- Foreign ministar Jadranko Prlic says the collective presidency should reach an agreement on the distribution of diplomatic posts by Thursday.
- U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees special envoy for former Yugoslavia, Carrol Faubert, said some 70,000 refugees are expected to return to their homes in Bosnia by the end of July.
- Faubert said most of refugees are returning to the Moslem-Croat federation, and few to the Serb entity. --Sarajevo newsroom, +387-71-663-864
